content: this is a story about getting out of my comfort zone as a miniature painter
and then ending up ruining half the project
on the part that i was too comfortable
with
hey guys welcome back to black magic craft this week's episode is sponsored
by the dragon trappers lodge and when they
first reached out to me to do a video using one of their 3d printable minis
i almost said no because while their models are absolutely beautiful
the theme for the month of august is heavily inspired by
japan and it's the type of thing that i wouldn't
normally gravitate towards i chose to go for it though i wanted to get
outside of my comfort zone and push myself to work on something
that was really different than my personal taste would normally dictate
i also wanted to use this as an excuse to try for the first
time painting fur patterns on a mini something that i've never done
and have always been pretty intimidated to try
so i picked kai a cat folk monk that
would force me to paint with a tiger fur pattern these models are
really cool in the fact that they come with multiple options for their hands
and weapons and like spell effects this guy
had four different options to choose from for each hand
and i wasn't sure which i would want to use so i printed out a couple of them
initially i thought that i would use the cool fire spell option
but in the end i decided to go with one of them holding the weapon
and one of them just being a clenched fist i thought these two
best highlighted the really dynamic pose of this sculpt
and despite being really small pieces they printed out really well
and were modeled with keyed slots to make assembly really easy
there was of course some small seams and gaps that needed filling
and i opted to use some really fast setting two-part epoxy putty
for this this isn't a hobby product this is something that you'd find in the
adhesive section of your big box hardware store
and it's meant for small repairs it's great because it dries rock hard
and is sandable in just a few minutes way better than waiting several hours
for milliput or green stuff to cure but the trade-off is
that you have almost no working time you only got like
two or three minutes to get your piece done
i opted to use rattle can primers because they also
dry a lot faster than the vallejo surface primer that i often use
and i really wanted to move on to painting right away
i was really excited and nervous to tackle the tiger fur
i've never done this before i have no experience with it
and i haven't even watched any tutorials on it
so i just sort of guessed my way through the whole process
i picked an orange that seemed suitably toned for tiger fur
thinned it and applied it with an airbrush i was patient
and did several light coats the xenotho highlight primer that i had applied
created natural shadows and highlights and it worked pretty well with the
orange that was not that opaque and you know as some
other colors might be now for the fun part adding the white
underbelly fur i had absolutely no idea how to do this
effectively with a brush so i didn't i just continued with the
airbrush with my psi set very low and a very gentle pressure
on the trigger i applied the white to the appropriate
areas even with rudimentary airbrush skills this was
actually an incredibly easy and effective process i was even
feeling confident enough at this point to continue and
block out the white parts of his clothing using the airbrush
coloring within the line so to speak on very small areas is not something i try
very often with airbrush and i think i've been doing a disservice
to myself by avoiding it while i didn't get it perfect i was able
to do a pretty effective job and it saved me a lot of time at this
point though i did need to move on to normal brush
painting and the first step would be to correct the areas of airbrush overspray
this really wasn't that much to do and frankly i was feeling pretty damn
pleased with how he was looking even at this early stage
i could then move on to blocking out all the other main colors with a base coat
i do not have steady hands in fact i fight against some rather strong tremors
every bit of shaky hand painting advice i've heard
be it elbows on the table arms against a desk or even the rubber band method
well none of them work for me personally what does work for me though
is this one specific painting position if i sit back
relax my body and keep my hand holding the model firmly against my chest
along with my forearm of my painting arm i am able to
mitigate my shakes almost entirely this position
is a lifesaver for me and it's something i recommend you try if you also struggle
with shakes it might not work for you but it's worth
a shot he was looking pretty decent with just
the major colors blocked in but it was time for that big
intimidating part of the paint job the stripes i was really nervous about
this because i'd never done it before and because fixing errors would be kind
of difficult as the orange and white had been
airbrushed on so matching touch-ups with a brush could be
really hard but i forced myself to just relax and get
into it and honestly it wasn't that hard my stripes may not be entirely accurate
to real life but i think in the end they sell the
idea well enough and certainly look good enough from a few
feet away that you usually view a mini i think if i were to do this a few more
times i could probably bang out some pretty believable animal patterns
eyes however are another story they are always really tough and they were
especially tough on this guy but i did get them kind of decent i really
wanted to put a wash on basically every part of the model mostly to get into the
recesses of all the color transitions and to tone down some of the brighter
colors my worry though was how it would make
the fur look i wasn't so worried about the orange
part but was justifiably concerned about the white areas
as it would be hard to bring back up the highlights where
there were black stripes in hindsight i suppose i could have left the stripes
until after the wash stage now i could go back
into each color and simply bring up the highlights and
mitigate the dirty staining effect that the washes can have
i actually think that on this model i would have been better served thinning
my washes but i'm still pretty content with how it
worked out my highlighting process is pretty basic
i go in with the color i used for the base coat and hit all the highest areas
then i lighten that color one or two times and progressively make the
highlights smaller i don't really do too much blending this
is really easy with colors like the vibrant blue on the
pants but it's a lot more tricky on things like whites and reds with red
in particular adding white to the highlights just
makes them look pink on this guy i tried using some
vibrant orange to brighten it up along with just a little bit of white
and i think this worked better than just adding white but it still has that
kind of pink highlight effect the fur was kind of tricky again because
of the stripes but thankfully it didn't need too much
a lot of the highest points were actually in areas that were just
orange in the white areas i essentially repainted the white
and had to redo the stripes but this honestly wasn't that big of a deal
he looked good but his eyes were looking especially derpy
i attempted to fix them but kept making them worse and worse it took me about 20
attempts to get it back to looking just decent so while i
fudge around with that let me tell you a bit more about the
sponsor the dragon trappers lodge is a monthly patreon-based service for
getting 3d printable miniatures for your
tabletop games for only 10 bucks a month you get access to a set of unique models
with a different theme every month the running
theme through every month however are the dragons and the dragon trappers
each month there is a unique gargantuan scale dragon model included
and the characters are the dragon trappers
the models are less focused on generic monsters or
hordes and are more focused on characters
and in terms of the monster or dragons that are included they also provide
5th edition dnd stat blocks every month when you join up you get a great welcome
pack a coupon code for a discount for their
previous models that are sold on myminifactory.com
and for 3d printing rookies like myself all the models come with pre-supported
options making them drag and drop and super easy
i'll put a link to their patreon in the video description so you can check them
out and get more details i didn't manage to get the eyes to a
point that i loved but i got them to a point where i was comfortable just
giving up and saying good enough i was really
anxious and excited to move on to making the nice scenic base and i didn't want
to work on the eyes anymore now i love the pose of this mini and how
it actually looked on the stick that i was using for painting
so i figured i'd make a base that had him balancing on a little wood post
i cut a piece of mdf but opted to not go for a rectangle i love creating bases
that change or slice through the viewer's perspective i
thought this shape would be really interesting
i sealed the edges of the mdf with super glue because i had plans of using
leftover gift cards to veneer the edges i realized quickly that i made the base
longer than a gift card so i had to quickly remedy
that thankfully the cut-off was also usable to build up
the height on one side my plan was to make a little shoreline
and have them standing on a wood post in some water
using the old gift card i started cutting up the frame
which would work as sort of a dam for the modeling compound later
and create a really durable finish for the outside where i didn't have to worry
about things shrinking unfortunately i realized after the first
piece that despite feeling like plastic amazon
gift cards are in fact just paper before continuing down that bad
path i just ripped it off and found a different card that was
actually plastic i really took my time with this
i got the shapes perfect and i got the seams really well bonded
blended and sanded super glue baking soda and sanding this gave me a frame
that i was really content with i was really pleased with myself for
putting in that effort here and excitedly moved on to the modeling
compound i used the stuff from geek gaming which
is very similar to sculptor mode but actually dries harder and faster
with my frame in place it was really easy to fill and shape the tiny
coastline and while it was wet i made a small
indentation for the post and glued it in place
and when i printed out the mini i also printed out the included base that they
had designed for it not knowing at that point how i'd be
finishing the model since i was doing this big scenic base
it wouldn't get used but i really loved that little bamboo shoot
detail and wanted to make use of them i gotta
say i'm impressed both with the pre-supported files they gave me
and with my any cubic photon for printing out these tiny bamboo branches
and leaves without any issue it's really remarkable
what we can do with at-home printing if you stop and think about it
if time wasn't a factor on this project i probably would have gone and printed a
whole bunch of these to just cover the whole area and that
would have looked really cool there really wasn't much to paint i'd be
doing full ground cover so it was just a matter of painting the
wood post and the bamboo before moving on
i wanted to make use of some of the geek gaming base ready materials on this one
they're awesome because they don't require any painting they just look good
as is i picked one that i thought would look
best for a japanese beach and got to work covering the base in the
fast drying glue this glue is super sticky and stays tacky forever
so i was really careful not to get it on the edges
after applying the base ready ground covers and sands i hid it with scenic
cement to lock it all in i was so damn excited about how this was
looking honestly i was totally thrilled it
really was gonna look like a little slice out of
real life this satisfaction and excitement is what
would make the next steps outcome so devastating once the base was dry i
prepared for the resin water pour i took my time getting it really well
masked off and dabbed and i grabbed some resin
in the past i would have used five-minute epoxy for this but it's
pretty thick and i remembered that i had some clear
smooth cast 325 on hand that i never ended up using
for another project i knew this would be way easier to pour
and it would flow really nicely so i opted to give it a go
but this is where i listened to my heart instead of my brain
my heart was saying yeah man go for it it's gonna look
awesome but my brain was saying hey man you've never used this stuff before so
you should probably do a test pour but my heart said no man screw it just
mix it up add in a few drops of wash to tint it
what could go wrong and my brain said yeah but um you don't
know how this will react uh why don't you do just a tiny test first i mean it
sets up in minutes what have you got to lose in the end my
stupid heart won out and told my brain to shut up
and i mixed in a few tiny drops of wash and just poured it onto my piece
what a massively stupid move
well this is why when you're working with materials or chemicals that
haven't really worked with before you should probably test
how they're going to interact with other things before using them on a piece that
you put a lot of work into i made the mistake of just winging it
and a lot of time that's fine this time it was not fine i've mixed
paints and inks and these washes with five minute epoxy
so many times and had no issue and for some reason
i just thought it would be fine with this stuff i suppose
this is actually like a polyurethane which reacts badly with water it says
polymethylene polyphenol whatever these are chemicals i don't
know what they mean it wasn't a reaction of the glue or anything on the base
because the leftover stuff also reacted in the cup and it foamed up
like crazy it's pretty neat actually it could
be cool for something else this base is ruined which is a shame
because everything else about it turned out really nice i don't have time
now to redo this all over again so i'm just
gonna cut my losses make a tiny little simple base for this
guy and uh call it yeah lessons learned
i really did not have the heart nor the
time to make that base all over again so i
just went with a very fast one-inch base i even used the post that he had already
been on for painting and some more of the base ready ground
cover and within a few minutes i still ended up with a really nice
display base i greatly regret screwing up the bigger
scenic base that i had put so much effort into but in the end it wasn't for
nothing i learned some valuable lessons in the
process it was a great reminder that when you're using new materials
on something really important you should test them out first and it made me
realize that i may be able to use this failure in a controlled way in the
future to make some kind of cool foamy effect
at the end of the day this project was about painting that
tiger model and i'm really happy with how it turned out
and i'm pretty proud of myself for overcoming the intimidation to paint fur
on a miniature so what do you guys think i hope you
enjoyed living vicariously through my failures on this one and i'm really
happy that i was able to make those mistakes
for you so that you don't have to if you enjoyed this video be sure to give it a
like and let me know in the comments section below
if you want to check out more of the cool models available from dragon
trapper's lodge i will put a link in the video description below
to them so you can check them out join up and get some cool minis to
do up yourself if you want to pick up any tools or supplies your own hobby
needs or you wonder what some of the stuff that i use regularly are be sure
to check out blackmagicraft.ca there i've put together an essential
equipment page that explains and links to most of the stuff that i use
if you enjoy these videos that i make every weekend you want to help me keep
making them for the community this community that is growing at a
alarming and amazing rate the best way you can do that is by supporting the
channel on patreon it's through that support that
i'm able to dedicate my time effort and resources
to these videos every week and by joining the blackmagic craft fellowship
you can help me keep doing it that's it for this week guys
i will see you again next week cheers i wonder if i can break this off and
no man this thing is solid oh wait wait sweet i can still use this
win
